title: Intraventricular Neurilemmoma (Schwannoma): Shall GFAP Immunostaining Be Regarded as a Histogenetical Tag or as a Mere Histomimetical Trait?
patient: A 16-year-old boy without any pathological, genetic, or familial history of significance suffered from headaches and intermittent blurry vision during six months; he got alarmed when his left eye vision was completely lost and presented to an urgent care facility. Magnetic resonance imaging scans showed an intraventricular, irregularly nodular, space-occupying lesion emerging from the posterior horn of the left lateral ventricle (). A gray-yellow tumour attached to the glomus choroideum was excised in integrum by the surgeon; histopathological examination disclosed a biphasic neoplasm laid out in densely packed fascicles of spindle cells with elongated nuclei (Antoni A pattern) as well as loosely clustered, hypocellular areas in a myxoid background (Antoni B pattern) (). Although Verocay bodies were not conspicuous, some blood vessels had hyalinised walls () while a reticulin lattice enveloped every single cell (). Senescent changes were also present, with isolated cells in the Antoni B areas displaying a round, voluminous, eosinophilic cytoplasm with a displaced atypical nucleus; some of them even resembled a gemistocytic morphophenotype (Figures –). The immunohistochemistry panel confirmed the diagnosis of neurilemmoma: PS100(+), collagen IV(+), and vimentin(+) (Figures and ), but also unveiled a diffuse labelling for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) in both Antony patterns (Figures and ). Thus, according to the aforementioned traits, the case was regarded as an intraventricular neurilemmoma.
